lawu.util.iterator
Class Iterators

java.lang.Object
  lawu.util.iterator.Iterators

public class Iterators
extends Object

Utility methods for manipulating iterators and iterable structures. The ultimate goal is to have an intuitive interface for straightforwardly dealing with all kinds of traversals.

For example, the iterator() method comes in numerous flavors. Its intent is to give the most logical iterator based on the argument(s). The method not only supports "obvious" iterables, such as Lists and arrays, but can also be used to iterate over the matching groups of a MatchResult, the characters of a CharSequence, the Nodes in a NodeList, and hopefully (eventually) anything else over which it may be philosophically desirable to iterate. Design pattern addicts rejoice: calling iterator() with no arguments will return a null iterator (not null, silly, just an iterator with has no elements). Similarly, calling it with a single element will return a single element iterator.

In addition to providing a variety of iterators, this class comes with methods for concisely accomplishing some common tasks, such as sorting, filtering, joining multiple iterators, or defining mapping involving all elements of a traversal. A neat trick is to: 

 import static lawu.util.iterator.Iterators.*;
...and then you can map, grep, or join to your heart's desire. You won't win any code brevity contests (this is still Java), but you might make a few Perl hackers smile.

All iterators returned by this class are subclasses of UniversalIterator, which means that you can use them whether you need an Iterable, a Java Iterator, a Gang of Four iterator, or even an Enumeration. Adapter methods are also provided for converting any of these interfaces to UniversalIterators.

Author:
Miorel-Lucian Palii

iterator

public static UniversalIterator<File> iterator(File file)
Returns an iterator over all the files in the directory hierarchy with the specified root. That is, this method is similar to the Unix find utility: if the File given to this method is a directory, the returned iterator will recurse through the directory tree in a depth-first manner. If the argument represents a normal file, the iterator will have a single element, the File itself. Directory tree nodes on the same level will be traversed in lexicographical order based on path, in a system-dependent manner (case-sensitive on Windows, case-insensitive on Unix).

Parameters:
file - root of the directory hierarchy to traverse
Returns:
an iterator over the directory hierarchy

iterator

public static UniversalIterator<String> iterator(Reader reader)

iterator

public static UniversalIterator<String> iterator(InputStream stream)

map

public static <T,U> UniversalIterator<U> map(Mapper<? super T,? extends U> mapper,
                                             Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Maps the elements of a traversal using the specified mapping function. The mapping is done lazily, i.e. the backing mapper does not get to see the elements of the mapped traversal until the returned iterator is explicitly asked for an element. Defining a mapping function with side effects might be a bad idea, but if you insist on applying it to all elements without doing anything else, you may find the traverse() method of use.

Type Parameters:
T - the mapping function's domain (the type of the input traversal)
U - the mapping function's range (the type over which the returned iterator iterates )
Parameters:
mapper - the mapping function
iterator - the traversal to map
Returns:
an iterator that performs the same traversal as the input but which applies the mapping function to each element before returning it

filter

public static <T> UniversalIterator<T> filter(Filter<? super T> filter,
                                              Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Keeps only those elements of a traversal which pass the specified filter.

Type Parameters:
T - the type over which the returned iterator iterates
Parameters:
filter - the filtering method
iterator - the traversal to filter
Returns:
an iterator that gives only those elements of the input which pass the specified filter

sort

public static <T extends Comparable<T>> UniversalIterator<T> sort(Iterator<? extends T> iterator)
Orders a traversal using the default comparison method.

Type Parameters:
T - the type over which the iteration takes place
Parameters:
iterator - the traversal to sort
Returns:
an iterator which gives the same elements as the input but sorted in order according to the default comparison method of the input type

traverse

public static void traverse(Iterator<?> iterator)
Traverses all of the elements of an iterator from the beginning, doing nothing. This could be useful primarily for forcing evaluation of lazy methods, such as map().

Parameters:
iterator - iterator to traverse
